    <item>
      <title>Everton hope to tempt Ronald Koeman with lure of record transfer budget</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/everton-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez-goodison-park-</link>
      <description>• Roberto Martínez fired after three seasons in the job<br />• Blues draw up a working shortlist of Dutchmen<br /><p>Everton want Ronald Koeman to succeed Roberto Martínez and hope to lure the Southampton coach with the promise of the biggest transfer budget in their history.</p><p>Farhad Moshiri, Everton’s new major shareholder, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/roberto-martinez-sacked-everton" title="">sacked Martínez on Thursday</a> and has earmarked Southampton’s manager as his preferred replacement. The British-Iranian billionaire faces a challenge to prise the 53-year-old from St&nbsp;Mary’s, however, even with Koeman yet to commit to a new contract and having just over 12 months remaining on his deal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/everton-ronald-koeman-roberto-martinez-goodison-park-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dick Pound promises IOC will not derail Tokyo 2020 corruption inquiry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/dick-pound-ioc-tokyo-2020-corruption</link>
      <description><p>• French prosecutors investigating payments from Tokyo 2020 bid<br>• ‘We would not try to discourage them from where the trail led,’ says Pound</p><p>Dick Pound, the veteran IOC member, has said French prosecutors should follow the trail of corruption “wherever it leads” after they <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/french-financial-prosecutors-confirm-investigation-into-tokyo-2020-bid-olympics-black-tidings">confirmed an investigation</a> into alleged seven-figure payments from the successful Tokyo 2020 Olympic bid to a secret account linked to the son of the disgraced former IAAF president Lamine Diack.</p><p>French prosecutors confirmed they were examining a string of potential offences including aggravated money laundering, corruption and bribery involving more than $2m (£1.4m) in suspicious payments apparently made to a bank account linked to Papa Massata Diack, the marketing consultant whose father was an influential International Olympic Committee member for 14 years.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/dick-pound-ioc-tokyo-2020-corruption">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Premier League: 10 things to look out for this weekend</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/13/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend</link>
      <description><p>Can Arsenal finish above Tottenham once more, will Spurs take advantage of Newcastle’s relegation and can Southampton secure European football?</p><p>An optimistic reading of Arsenal’s season might start with emphasis on how they were the least wobbly and underachieving of the supposed Big Four this season – Manchester City, Manchester United and Chelsea should all finish below them, barring an unlikely result against Aston Villa at the Emirates on Sunday. Of greater significance to the club’s fans, increasingly jaded by the trumpeting of “stable” top-four finishes, would be the chance to steal second place from Tottenham and finish above their rivals for the 21st season in succession. In lots of ways it would be aburdly undeserved. Arsenal have been out of the title race for a couple of months and though their football has purred at times, it has rarely thrilled in the manner of Tottenham’s. But Arsène Wenger knows how to engineer strong finishes to a campaign, even when – <em>especially</em> when, his detractors might say – there is nothing much to play for. Victory over a notoriously inept and long-doomed Villa ought to be a given, while Spurs might find things tougher against another relegated but less ragged side in Newcastle. In a week in which Arsenal have suffered more injury woe with news that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/arsenal-danny-welbeck-nine-months-out-knee-surgery">Danny Welbeck faces nine months on the sidelines</a>, recent returnees Jack Wilshere (who impressed <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/08/manchester-city-arsenal-premier-league-match-report">at Manchester City last weekend</a>) and Santi Cazorla have a chance to decorate the final match of another unsatisfactory season. <strong>Tom Davies</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/13/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Russian doctors and athletes ‘switched urine samples’ at Sochi Olympics</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/russian-doctors-athletes-evaded-doping-tests</link>
      <description>• Former head of Russia’s national anti-doping lab admits to cheating tests<br />• Grigory Rodchenkov tells New York Times of widespread conspiracy<p>The former head of the Russian Anti-Doping Agency has revealed his part in an astonishing state-run doping programme before and during the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, which included supplying banned performance-enhancing substances to at least 15 medal winners and substituting tainted urine samples with clean ones during the Games so that they passed doping tests. The International Olympic Committee described the accusations as “very worrying” and called for them to be investigated immediately by the World Anti-Doping Agency .</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/french-financial-prosecutors-confirm-investigation-into-tokyo-2020-bid-olympics-black-tidings">French financial prosecutors confirm investigation into Tokyo 2020 bid</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/russian-doctors-athletes-evaded-doping-tests">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/kurtley-beale-signs-296m-deal-with-uk-rugby-club-wasps</link>
      <description><ul><li>Wallabies star to become highest paid player in England with £1.5m deal<br></li><li>Beale’s 60 Test caps mean he will still be eligible to play for Australia</li></ul><p>Wallabies star Kurtley Beale has reportedly signed a deal with Wasps which will make him the highest paid player in England. The Times in London is reporting Beale will become the biggest earner in English rugby after agreeing to a deal worth $A2.96 m (£1.5m).</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-star-junior-paulo-disguises-himself-and-plays-in-third-grade-park-match">NRL star Junior Paulo disguises himself and plays in third-grade park match</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/kurtley-beale-signs-296m-deal-with-uk-rugby-club-wasps">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jason Day shoots record-equalling round at Players Championship</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett</link>
      <description>• Shane Lowry and Justin Rose two behind leader at Sawgrass<br />• Jordan Spieth level-par 72, Danny Willett signs for 70<p>The angst Jordan Spieth suffered by virtue of closing his opening round at the Players Championship with a seven, the one number that may bring him out in a cold sweat, surely intensified with a glance towards one of the his playing partners. Jason Day, who has succeeded Spieth as the world No1, endorsed his status once more with a course record-equalling 63. Day had birdie putts at all 18 holes.</p><p>As Day tapped in for birdie at the 9th, their 18th, Spieth was about to three putt for a double bogey. Spieth’s frustration at a 72 on a day of generally excellent scoring was compounded by that seven; the same scorecard aberration that fatally undermined his hopes of defending the Masters, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/11/danny-willett-masterrs-2016-jordan-spieth-lee-westood" title="">owing to a capitulation at Augusta National’s 12th hole</a>. Spieth later insisted his Thursday score did not appropriately represent his performance. “I really only had two bad swings today,” he said. “I’m hitting the ball great.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Novak Djokovic shaken at Italian Open but Andy Murray eases through</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/andy-murray-beats-jeremy-chardy-italian-open-david-goffin-tennis</link>
      <description>• Djokovic recovers from first-set bagel to beat Thomaz Bellucci<br />• World No1 faces Rafael Nadal in quarter-finals; Murray plays David Goffin<p>They say nothing lasts for ever in the Eternal City but this was ridiculous. In a day of fantasy tennis that might have been scripted by Federico Fellini, the world No1, Novak Djokovic, considered to be approaching invincibility in his sport, went 33 minutes and 47 seconds before he could raise his arms in mock triumph to celebrate winning a game against the world No37, Thomaz Bellucci, in the third round of the Italian Open.</p><p>At that point, the Serb had won only 15 points to the Brazilian’s 34 and was struggling to come to terms with having been bagelled for the first time since Roger Federer kept him scoreless in the first set in Cincinnati five years ago.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/andy-murray-beats-jeremy-chardy-italian-open-david-goffin-tennis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Police watchdog to investigate Hillsborough inquest spin claims</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/police-watchdog-ipcc-investigate-hillsborough-inquest-spin-claims</link>
      <description><p>South Yorkshire police communications specialist says she was given ‘unethical’ instructions to try to influence coverage</p><p>The Independent Police Complaints Commission has launched an investigation into allegations that South Yorkshire police <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/05/south-yorkshire-police-tried-to-spin-evidence-at-hillsborough-inquests">tried to influence</a> daily media coverage of the Hillsborough inquests and spin what the force considered to be evidence favourable to it.</p><p>Hayley Court, a communications specialist hired by South Yorkshire police in 2014 specifically to work on the inquests, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/05/south-yorkshire-police-tried-to-spin-evidence-at-hillsborough-inquests">told the Guardian last week</a> that she believed she had been given “unethical” instructions to spin coverage for the force. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/police-watchdog-ipcc-investigate-hillsborough-inquest-spin-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Luke Gale leads Castleford to crushing victory over Leeds Rhinos</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/leeds-castleford-super-league-match-report</link>
      <description>• Leeds Rhinos 12-52 Castleford Tigers<p>So, where now for Leeds Rhinos? The obvious answer is the Qualifiers and a relegation battle in the second half of this most extraordinary of seasons, and this was a performance that prompted yet more questions about the spectacular demise of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/oct/02/leeds-rhinos-st-helens-super-league-semi-final-match-report" title="">last year’s treble winners</a>.</p><p>The more optimistic Leeds fan would have argued that a combined losing margin of just 12 points from their last two games suggested the defending champions were slowly getting their act together. But this? This was a complete annihilation, and the firmest evidence yet that Leeds are destined for the bottom four.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/leeds-castleford-super-league-match-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Kenya’s Olympic participation in doubt after Wada recommendation</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/kenya-olympic-doubt-wada-non-compliant</link>
      <description>• African country declared non-compliant by review committee<br />• IOC will decide whether to ban Kenya from the Rio Games<p>The World Anti-Doping Agency’s compliance review committee has recommended Kenya be declared non-compliant, casting doubt on the country’s participation in this summer’s Olympic Games.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/07/kenya-handed-extension-anti-doping-code-olympics-iaaf-wada" title="">Having missed two deadlines</a> to show it was addressing serious worries about its anti-doping efforts, Kenya passed legislation last month to create a new national anti-doping agency. However that has not been enough to satisfy Wada.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/kenya-olympic-doubt-wada-non-compliant">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/serena-williams-dog-food-italian-open</link>
      <description><ul><li>World No1 samples dish meant for her pet dog Chip</li><li>Goes on to beat Christian McHale in third round in Rome</li></ul><p>The benefits of special diets for athletes have been well documented, but Serena Williams may have taken things too far on Wednesday when she decided to sample her pet dog’s dinner.</p><p>Williams is playing in the Italian Open, and her hotel had prepared a special menu for her Yorkshire terrier, Chip, including a tempting salmon and rice dish. The world No1 sampled some of it, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRrze_N9IpI">telling fans on Snapchat</a>: “I ate a spoonful.       <title>Chiller: Kyrgios 'doesn’t understand what it means to be an Olympian'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/chiller-kyrgios-doesnt-understand-what-it-means-to-be-an-olympian</link>
      <description><ul><li>Australian team boss sets her sights on Kyrgios after Tomic withdrawal</li><li>Kyrgios all but dares Rio Games selectors to leave him out of team</li></ul><p>Nick Kyrgios is now in Australian Olympic team boss Kitty Chiller’s sights after Bernard Tomic’s Rio withdrawal.&nbsp;Tomic and Kyrgios were both warned by Chiller last week in response to behavioural issues on and off the court.</p><p>Chiller refused to speculate on whether Tomic had beaten selectors to the punch by ruling himself out of the Rio Games but made her views on Kyrgios clear, saying his “ill-advised” response to being put on notice by the AOC showed he did not know what it meant to be an Australian Olympian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/chiller-kyrgios-doesnt-understand-what-it-means-to-be-an-olympian">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Hillsborough victims honoured with freedom of Liverpool</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/13/hillsborough-victims-honoured-freedom-of-liverpool</link>
      <description><p>Council also awards honour to Kenny Dalglish and wife Marina, former bishop James Jones and campaigner Phil Scraton</p><p>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/ng-interactive/2016/apr/06/hillsborough-victims-the-96-people-whose-lives-were-cut-short">96 people</a> who died in the Hillsborough disaster in 1989 are to be posthumously awarded the freedom of the city of Liverpool, the local council has announced.</p><p>Kenny Dalglish, the manager of Liverpool FC at the time, and his wife, Marina, are also to be awarded the freedom of the city, along with the former <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/oct/18/hillsborough-panel-interview-james-jones">bishop of Liverpool James Jones</a> and Prof Phil Scraton, a campaigner for the bereaved families’ cause.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/13/hillsborough-victims-honoured-freedom-of-liverpool">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>• Kvyat was dropped to junior Toro Rosso team and replaced by Max Verstappen<br />• ‘There was no real explanation to be honest. The decision was a bit of a shock’<p>A bitterly disappointed Daniil Kvyat has said he received no explanation for his sudden <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/05/red-bull-drop-daniil-kvyat-f1-max-verstappen" title="">dropping from the Red Bull team</a>, only four races into the Formula One season.     <item>
      <title>Bernard Tomic rules himself out of Rio Olympics Australian tennis team</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/bernard-tomic-rules-himself-out-of-rio-olympics-australian-tennis-team</link>
      <description><ul><li>Medal hopeful cites playing schedule and personal circumstances</li><li>AOC chef de mission Kitty Chiller had criticised ‘appalling’ behaviour</li></ul><p>Bernard Tomic has ruled himself out of the Rio Olympics, citing a busy playing schedule and personal circumstances. Tomic’s selection was under a cloud after he deliberately gave up a match point at a tournament in Madrid and said he didn’t care because he was worth $10m, leading Australian Olympic Committee chef de mission Kitty Chiller to describe his behaviour as “appalling”.</p><p>The 23-year-old Australian said although he has always given his all when wearing the green and gold his playing schedule is too busy to allow him to play at the Olympics this year and that the move was the best one for his career.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/bernard-tomic-rules-himself-out-of-rio-olympics-australian-tennis-team">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/australia-sport">Australia sport</category>

    <item>
      <title>Sri Lanka produce decent Test players despite system, says Kumar Sangakkara</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/sri-lanka-kumar-sangakkara-headingley-first-test-england</link>
      <description>• ‘Three-day cricket is not played to a standard that is acceptable’<br />• Headingley hosts first Test against England from Thursday<p>Kumar Sangakkara has bemoaned the domestic system in Sri Lanka that, in his view, means the country’s cricketers learning their trade at international level and makes their upcoming Test series<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/stuart-broad-england-jake-ball-sri-lanka-cricket" title=""> with England a battle to be competitive</a>.</p><p>Sangakkara, scorer of 12,400 Test runs, was part of the side that in 2014 capitalised on England’s angst following their Ashes whitewash in Australia to secure a 1-0 series victory under the then captain Mahela Jayawardene, with a tense 100-run win at Headingley, scene of next week’s first Test, that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/jun/24/sri-lanka-second-test-one-ball-left-end-england-resistance" title="">was secured off the penultimate ball of the match</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/sri-lanka-kumar-sangakkara-headingley-first-test-england">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>University of Dayton basketball star Steve McElvene dies at age of 20</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/steve-mcelvene-dead-university-of-dayton-basketball</link>
      <description><ul><li>Player had set school record for blocked shots last season</li><li>Cause of death remains unconfirmed after sudden collapse</li></ul><p>The University of Dayton center Steve McElvene has died suddenly at the age of 20, the school has confirmed. A cause of death has not yet been given. </p><p>“We are devastated at this news,” the Dayton coach Archie Miller said in a statement. “Any death is a tragedy, but for someone so young, who worked so hard to have his dreams within reach, it’s hard to put into words how painful this is. Our hearts and prayers go out to Steve’s family. My family, our team and our staff will have to pull together, not only in support of Steve’s family, but in support of each other at this terrible time.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/steve-mcelvene-dead-university-of-dayton-basketball">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Conor O’Shea rallies Harlequins for final shot at glory against Montpellier</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/conor-ohea-harlequins-european-challenge-cup-final-montpellier</link>
      <description>• Irish director of rugby leaves Quins to take charge of Italy next season<br />• Victory over in-form French side will clinch Champions’ Cup spot<p>Before his last stand as Harlequins’ director of rugby, Conor O’Shea has promised his side will “fire every bullet” in their bid to win the European Challenge Cup final Friday evening. Quins face daunting opponents in the shape of in-form Montpellier but O’Shea, who is leaving the club after six years in charge, expects his players to respond positively to the challenge.</p><p>Only last Saturday <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/07/harlequins-exeter-premiership-match-report" title="">Quins conceded a record 62 points at home to Exeter</a> Chiefs but O’Shea has made eight changes and hopes the return of experienced internationals such as Joe Marler, Adam Jones, James Horwill and Tim Visser will encourage a vigorous response at the Grand Stade de Lyon as they seek to secure not just a trophy but qualification for next season’s Champions’ Cup. The players can certainly expect an emotional pre-match speech from O’Shea, who is moving on to <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/mar/25/conor-oshea-italy-head-coach-mike-catt" title="">take charge of Italy’s national team</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/conor-ohea-harlequins-european-challenge-cup-final-montpellier">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/lewis-hamilton-formula-one-f1-mercedes-nico-rosberg-mclaren</link>
      <description><ul><li>Hamilton learned lessons from adversity in Japan during 2008 season</li><li>World champion says he felt a sense of betrayal when leaving McLaren</li></ul><p>Lewis Hamilton is confident he is able to come back from the setbacks he has suffered this season, noting that his ability to cope has improved hugely since he began his career in Formula One. The world champion insisted that he can move on from adversity – which on a previous occasion saw him shut himself in a hotel room for three days – with much more ease than early in his career.<br></p><p>Speaking in an interview for a US TV show, the Mercedes driver also admitted that he felt a sense of betrayal on leaving his previous team McLaren and that the intensity of the battle with his Mercedes team-mate Nico Rosberg is such that it is impossible for the two to be friends.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/lewis-hamilton-formula-one-f1-mercedes-nico-rosberg-mclaren">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Aitken steals win for Dragons after Wighton's horror pass</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/aitken-steals-win-for-dragons-after-wightons-horror-pass</link>
      <description><ul><li>St George Illawarra 16-12 Canberra Raiders at Kogarah</li><li>Wayward Jack Wighton pass sets up dramatic NRL extra time win</li></ul><p>A wayward Jack Wighton pass handed St George Illawarra a dramatic 16-12 golden-point NRL win over Canberra at Kogarah. Canberra kept the ball alive after the siren on Thursday night in the first stanza of extra time and Wighton inexplicably threw the Steeden to Euan Aitken, who raced 20m to claim the win.</p><p>At a darkened Jubilee Oval, which had one of its four light towers inoperable for the match due to a power outage in the area, Jarrod Croker became the Raiders’ highest pointscorer, passing David Furner with his 1224th career point to lock up the scores at 12-12 just before full time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/aitken-steals-win-for-dragons-after-wightons-horror-pass">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>NRL star Junior Paulo disguises himself and plays in third-grade park match</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-star-junior-paulo-disguises-himself-and-plays-in-third-grade-park-match</link>
      <description><ul><li>Brother-in-law suspended for one year after sending Eels forward on</li><li>Rugby union administrator labels incident ‘sheer stupidity’</li></ul><p>Junior Paulo’s brother-in-law has been suspended from rugby union for a year for sending the Parramatta forward on to the field in a third grade park match. Eels coach Brad Arthur said on Thursday the club had dealt with the incident “in-house” and confirmed Paulo will line up for the Eels on Friday night when they take on South Sydney.</p><p>But the man who sent him on the field during Oatley’s 17-10 rugby union win over Beecroft in Sydney wasn’t so lucky. Oatley third-grade coach Hendry Lees – Paulo’s brother-in-law – was suspended for a year. The Samoan international wore headgear to disguise himself and played under an alias, coming on in the closing stages of the match on 30 April.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-star-junior-paulo-disguises-himself-and-plays-in-third-grade-park-match">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>• 58-year-old resigned as head of Board of Control for Cricket in India<br />• Becomes world governing body’s first elected independent chairman<p>Shashank Manohar will begin his new two-year term as International Cricket Council chairman with immediate effect, after being elected unopposed to the post.</p><p>Manohar is the world governing body’s first elected independent chairman, following amendments proposed by the board at its meeting last month.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/shashank-manohar-elected-unopposed-independent-icc-chairman-cricket">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tony Cozier obituary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/tony-cozier-obituary</link>
      <description>West Indian cricket commentator whose lilting tones and forthright analysis brought the game to life<p>Tony Cozier, who has died aged 75 of cancer, was the consummate, constant reporter of Caribbean cricket for more than five decades. He was recognised by cricket followers around the world more by his voice than his appearance. A surprising number of devotees did not realise that he was a white Bajan – a native of Barbados – yet all were captivated by the unmistakable, lilting tones of his commentary, while his readers trusted his clear and forthright analysis of West Indies cricket through thick and thin.</p><p>To watch Tony at work at a Test match was an education. He would glide between the TV commentary box to the (much smaller) radio box, then back to the press room where he would construct a couple of pieces for <a href="http://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/81136/icon-gone" title="">the Nation</a> newspaper of Barbados, then perhaps another for the Independent in the UK. It seemed such an effortless process, albeit without a minute wasted.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/tony-cozier-obituary">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/afl-players-association-pushing-for-a-share-of-league-revenue</link>
      <description><ul><li>AFLPA want a slice of overall revenue in collective bargaining agreement</li><li>League CEO Gillon McLachlan confirms ‘key demand’ of players</li></ul><p>AFL players are continuing their push for a percentage of the game’s overall revenue, with chief executive Gillon McLachlan saying they will be fairly rewarded. Following a meeting of the club chief executives in Melbourne on Thursday McLachlan confirmed the Collective Bargaining Agreement was on the agenda with the AFL Players’ Association seeking a lucrative new pay deal when it kicks in on 1 November.</p><p>McLachlan said he hoped the agreement could be concluded by July. He refused to go into details of the proposal or the response from club bosses but said the players’ main demand was the percentage payment.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/afl-players-association-pushing-for-a-share-of-league-revenue">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/nick-compton-england-squad-alex-hales-steven-finn-sri-lanka-cricket</link>
      <description>The Middlesex batsman looks the beneficiary of James Taylor’s retirement for the Sri Lanka series while Alex Hales and Steven Finn must rectify patchy form<p>In the end, after all the speculation, combinations and names hurled into the hat, there was very little at all up for grabs. One batting place certainly opened up for next week’s first Test against Sri Lanka at Headingley, the result of the unfortunate illness leading to <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/12/james-taylor-retire-heart-condition-notts-england" title="">James Taylor’s retirement</a>, which has gone to James Vince, the Hampshire captain. Meanwhile the Nottinghamshire pace bowler Jake Ball replaces Chris Woakes, who, with Steven Finn unfit, played in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/jan/26/england-south-africa-fourth-test-day-five-kagiso-rabada" title="">England’s last Test</a> against South Africa in January.       <title>Roger Federer finds time catching up with him as French Open decision awaits | Kevin Mitchell</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/roger-federer-french-open-back-injury</link>
      <description>The 34-year-old’s record of 65 successive grand slam appearances could be ended by the back injury that not only threatens his place at Roland Garros later this month but reminds us he cannot carry on playing for ever<p>Roger Federer says he will not be at the French Open if the unspecified injury to his back does not improve sufficiently over the next 10 days for him to play with full freedom and, if he does start in Paris, he reckons his chances of doing well are “not great”.</p><p>So, we are a just little closer to knowing where the game’s greatest player stands at 34 as he starts to creak around the edges. The finish line remains a blur but is not so distant as it was even a few months ago.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/roger-federer-french-open-back-injury">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Everton put Roberto Martínez out of his agony amid the Wigan parallels | Paul Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/everton-roberto-martinez-wigan-parallels</link>
      <description>Despite a successful first season at Goodison, the Spaniard’s tactical failings gradually alienated Everton fans and by the end of his three-year reign he appeared to lose the dressing room too<p>Roberto Martínez cut such a lonely and despondent figure in the television interview studio following the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report" title="">3-0 defeat at Sunderland</a> on Wednesday night it is no surprise Everton have released him early and spared him the ignominy of facing scornful home supporters in the final game of the season against Norwich on Sunday.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/10/roberto-martinez-everton-chelsea" title="">The manager lost the fans some time ago</a> and judging by the last couple of abject performances, lost the dressing room, too. The match at Sunderland, the second time in a week that Everton had provided only token resistance to opponents writing their own headlines, came three years to the day since Martínez’s greatest triumph, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/may/11/manchester-city-wigan-athletic-fa-cup" title="">the FA Cup win with Wigan Athletic</a> that brought him to the Merseyside club’s attention.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/everton-roberto-martinez-wigan-parallels">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tokyo Olympic Games corruption claims bring scandal back to the IOC | Sean Ingle</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/tokyo-olympic-games-2020-ioc-international-olympic-committee-corruption-bid-scandal</link>
      <description><p>Payments for members’ votes were supposed to be a thing of the past at the International Olympic Committee but new allegations will prompt fresh scrutiny</p><p>Bungs and secret bank accounts; shadowy figures on the take and make; the bidding process for major sporting events shown to be as transparent as an oil slick. The script might appear stale given the numerous tales of scandals and scoundrels at Fifa and the IAAF, the global guardians of football and athletics respectively, in recent years. But now there is a fresh and intriguing twist.</p><p>The grandest sporting organisation of all, the International Olympic Committee (IOC), has stood aloof while the staggering tales of corruption surrounding World Cup and World Athletics’ Championships bids seeped out. We are different, the IOC insisted. We have reformed. And with few dissenting voices or evidence to the contrary, the bad old days of the late 90s, when members’ votes were bought for enormous sums during feverish races to host Olympic Games, had become a distant memory.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/11/tokyo-olympic-games-2020-ioc-international-olympic-committee-corruption-bid-scandal">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Back to the future: how football’s tactical evolution has begun to invoke the past | Jonathan Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/future-football-tactics-evolution-invoke-the-past</link>
      <description>Leicester and Atlético Madrid found success after discovering opponents had forgotten the answers to counter their old-fashioned tactics – what does this mean for the Barçajax philosophy?<p>For a time, the orthodoxy was that the only way, at least for clubs that saw themselves as part of the elite, was the Barçajax way. Pep Guardiola’s Barcelona were seen as the model, producing football of extraordinary brilliance, pushing the boundaries of what had previously been thought possible in terms of control of possession. Others followed, many of them directed by coaches who had, like Guardiola, been at Barcelona in the late 90s and who represented the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/aug/13/jose-mourinho-louis-van-gaal-barcelona-shaped-seven-top-coaches" title="">blossoming of Johan Cruyff’s ideals into orthodoxy</a>.</p><p>That consensus has collapsed over the past couple of seasons. It’s not just <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/dec/22/devil-and-jose-mourinho" title="">José Mourinho waging his Oedipal war</a> against the club that formed him. Counterattacking is back in vogue. Tactical history is always like this: there have always been cycles of thesis and antithesis, but it’s the route the resulting syntheses are taking that makes this such a fascinating time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/future-football-tactics-evolution-invoke-the-past">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>NRL Indigenous round a 'celebratory' moment of cultural pride | Paul Connolly</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-indigenous-round-a-celebratory-moment-of-cultural-pride</link>
      <description><p>Not only a showcase of sporting achievement and pride, the NRL’s Indigenous round provides Australia with a positive glimpse of Indigenous culture</p><p>Dean Widders could have let it slide. He could have dismissed it as a verbal haymaker in the heat of battle and moved on. But he didn’t. No, after South Sydney Rabbitoh, and former teammate, Bryan Fletcher, called him a “black cunt” during a 2005 NRL match, Parramatta’s Widders chose to speak out about it, to willingly throw himself into the middle of a media and cultural whirlpool. Why? “Because unlike many other Indigenous people,” says Widders – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/jan/22/how-rugby-league-player-dean-widders-stared-racism-in-the-face-and-won">who has spoken of his distress in that moment</a> – “I had a chance to have my voice heard, and I knew I could be a positive influence on my people.”</p><p>Widders, now the NRL’s Indigenous welfare and education manager, is a great believer in the power of positivity. It’s one reason he’s a strong supporter of the NRL’s continuing efforts to acknowledge Indigenous culture and the enormous contribution Indigenous athletes have made to rugby league. Initiatives like this weekend’s “Indigenous round”, and the pre-season Indigenous All-Stars v World All-Stars match, serve a dual purpose, he believes. One is that they help the NRL’s Indigenous players “strengthen their relationship with their own heritage” while also conveying a positive message about Indigenous culture to non-Indigenous Australians.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-indigenous-round-a-celebratory-moment-of-cultural-pride">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/newcastle-relegation-championship-mike-ashley-board-rafael-benitez</link>
      <description>The startling reality is that despite spending £80m on new players this season – only Manchester City invested more – Newcastle have still ended up in this mess<p>So John Carver was right after all. A little over a year ago Newcastle United’s interim manager claimed even a world-class coach would struggle at St James’ Park and, sure enough, Rafael Benítez has vindicated his theory.</p><p>When, two months ago, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/11/newcastle-rafael-benitez-new-manager" title="">Benítez succeeded Steve McClaren,</a> he had 10 games to keep Newcastle in the Premier League and, justifiably, fancied his chances. Nine of those matches later – two won, three lost, four drawn – the Tynesiders are relegated but this costly tumble into the Championship is not remotely the Spaniard’s fault.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/12/newcastle-relegation-championship-mike-ashley-board-rafael-benitez">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Do AFL fans really still care about grudge matches like Dangerfield's return?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/do-afl-fans-really-still-care-about-grudge-matches-like-dangerfields-return</link>
      <description><p>As the Geelong man returns to Adelaide to face his old side, we might see whether grudge matches still resonate with AFL fans in 2016</p><p>In times such as these, guessing the precise motivations of AFL fans is a fool’s errand. But you do start asking yourself a few questions. For the price of his admission to Metricon stadium, should a grown man flanked by children really be entitled to lean across a fence and unload an ugly, vein-bulging stream of invective at such an affable, softly-spoken champion as Gary Ablett?</p><p>And in this era of equalisation, free agency and every-man-for-himself, get-the-money-while-you-can individualism, should even we fans who foot the bill really blame footballers for acting as we would in our own careers in seeking out the most lucrative and satisfying employment available? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/do-afl-fans-really-still-care-about-grudge-matches-like-dangerfields-return">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/afl">AFL</category>

    <item>
      <title>Will the Gronkowskis or Currys replace the Mannings as America's sports family?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/mannings-most-dominant-american-sports-family</link>
      <description><p>With the retirement of Peyton, the Mannings’ athletic dominance has ended. There are plenty of candidates to fill the void though</p><p>More than three months have passed since Peyton Manning ended his career and Denver’s search for his replacement has been an ongoing story. After Brock Osweiler went to the Texans, the Broncos s<a href="http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14951086/denver-broncos-trade-quarterback-mark-sanchez">igned Mark Sanchez</a>, reportedly kicked the tires on Colin Kaepernick, Ryan Fitzpatrick and Sam Bradford, and <a href="http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25583365/emmanuel-sanders-tells-paxton-lynch-hes-demaryius-thomas">drafted Paxton Lynch</a>. </p><p>Yet while the Broncos have temporary patched their QB hole with Sanchez and hope to have plugged for the long-term with Lynch, a large and important void remains with an impact stretching far beyond Denver: who is American sport’s reigning power family now? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/mannings-most-dominant-american-sports-family">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'If you don't talk, it doesn't work': how sport helps autistic people</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/how-sport-helps-autistic-people-effective-treatment-autism</link>
      <description><p>The intrinsic importance of social skills in sport means it can be a more effective treatment than traditional therapy</p><p> “A few years ago, I couldn’t even go out of the house by myself,” says Daniel Mynott. That was before he started getting involved in sport. “Now, I go all over London and the country. I have so many friends I’ve lost count. I even have my own car.”</p><p>Mynott has autism. A few years ago, when he was 15, <a href="http://www.thechangefoundation.org.uk/">the Change Foundation</a> turned up at his school and encouraged him to try taking part in sport. “I hated sport,” he says. “I was lazy as hell, but they saw my potential, they saw I was good with people. Gradually, I fell in love with it.”<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/how-sport-helps-autistic-people-effective-treatment-autism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunderland relegate Newcastle and Norwich – Football Weekly Extra</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/may/12/sunderland-relegate-newcastle-norwich-football-weekly-extra-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Sam Allardyce saves his Premier League skin again. Plus, the battle for the Champions League spots, John Terry’s Stamford Bridge barbecue and the curious case of Joey Barton’s Championship winner’s medal </p><p>On today’s<strong> Football Weekly Extra</strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/acjimbo">AC Jimbo</a></strong> is joined by the triple threat of <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/bglendenning">Barry Glendenning</a></strong>, <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/john_ashdown">John Ashdown</a></strong> and <strong><a href="http://www.twitter.com/greggbakowski">Gregg Bakowski</a></strong> to look back on <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland’s victory at Everton</a>, a result which <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/11/sam-allardyce-sunderland-escape-route-everton-rafael-benitez">confirmed the relegations of both Newcastle and Norwich</a>. <a href="http://www.claretandhugh.info/wp-content/uploads/Big-Sam_800x400-800x380.jpg">Oh, Big Sam, how could you</a>?</p><p>With the top and the bottom of the Premier League therefore sorted, the drama of the final weekend involves <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/liverpool-manchester-united-hopes-european-hopes">the Champions League spots</a>. Will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/09/tottenham-finishing-above-arsenal-good-feeling-harry-kane">Arsenal pip Spurs</a> to second place? Will it be United or City who finish fourth? Or will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/west-ham-david-sullivan-poor-judgement-supporters">West Ham inflict yet damage pain on United’s coach</a>? (That’s LVG, people).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/audio/2016/may/12/sunderland-relegate-newcastle-norwich-football-weekly-extra-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sunderland’s Sam Allardyce calls on Ellis Short to ‘think bigger’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/sunderland-sam-allardyce-ellis-short-meeting</link>
      <description>• Allardyce preparing for ‘critical’ meeting with Sunderland owner<br />• ‘We have to think much bigger, have much more ambition’<p>Sam Allardyce never made it home after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/sunderland-everton-premier-league-match-report">Sunderland’s survival-securing home win against Everton</a> on Wednesday night. Instead the manager spent “a few” convivial hours drinking with Ellis Short, the owner, but the pair are likely to be stone cold sober when they meet next week to discuss their summer transfer budget and strategy.</p><p>“I’m only just overcoming a hangover,” said Allardyce, who checked into a hotel in the early hours of Thursday. “But my next meeting with Ellis will be critical as to whether we struggle again next season or not. The big thing is the new players we bring in and how we can improve the team. We have to move away from the fact that we’re all so happy at being heroes for surviving. We have to think much bigger, have much more ambition.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/sunderland-sam-allardyce-ellis-short-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Borussia Dortmund sign Ousmane Dembélé from Rennes on five-year deal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/borussia-dortmund-sign-ousmane-dembele-from-rennes-on-five-year-deal</link>
      <description>• The 18-year-old is considered one of best young players in Europe<br />• ‘Concept at Borussia has totally convinced me,’ says Dembélé<p>Borussia Dortmund have signed the highly rated <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/23/ousmane-dembele-football-hottest-property-rennes-bayern-munich-ligue-1" title="">Ousmane Dembélé</a> from Rennes for an undisclosed fee. The 18-year-old, who had been watched by a host of European clubs, has signed a five-year contract with the Bundesliga club.</p><p>This season, the forward has scored 12 goals in Ligue 1 in 25 games and provided five assists. He was voted the best young player in France this season. “Dortmund have looked at me for a long time and have always been in close contact with me and their conduct has really impressed me,” he said.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/borussia-dortmund-sign-ousmane-dembele-from-rennes-on-five-year-deal">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mauricio Pochettino signs Tottenham contract extension until 2021</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mauricio-pochettino-signs-new-deal-future-tottenham-2021</link>
      <description>• Pochettino had been linked with move to Manchester United<br />• Several key players now expected to commit to long-term deals<p>Mauricio Pochettino has signed his new five-year contract at Tottenham Hotspur and a clutch of key players are now expected to commit to longer-term deals at the club.</p><p>The manager <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2016/apr/29/mauricio-pochettino-extends-tottenham-contract-to-2021-video" title="">announced two weeks ago</a> that he had reached a verbal agreement with the chairman, Daniel Levy, to extend his stay at White Hart Lane and it has since been a matter of finding time to complete the paperwork. Pochettino’s three assistants – Jesús Pérez, Miguel D’Agostino and Toni Jiménez – have also signed extensions to their contracts.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mauricio-pochettino-signs-new-deal-future-tottenham-2021">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Carrow Road club have just experienced a second relegation in three seasons but all is perhaps not lost<p>In the days ahead Alex Neil and his employer will sit down and talk about where Norwich are heading, other than to the Championship, and determine whether they will remain together.       <title>Danny Simpson to miss out on Leicester title celebrations after curfew order</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/danny-simpson-leicester-city-curfew-title-celebrations</link>
      <description>• Full-back ordered to wear ankle tag and be in by 10pm<br />• Defender did only half community service for assaulting ex-girlfriend<br /><p>The Leicester City full-back Danny Simpson will miss part of the title-winning celebrations and the club’s end-of-season party after a judge ordered he must serve a curfew immediately for assaulting his ex-girlfriend.</p><p>Simpson, 29, had only done half of the 300 hours he was sentenced to last June for assaulting Stephanie Ward, the mother of his child, in a row at their house in Worsley, Greater Manchester, in December 2014.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/danny-simpson-leicester-city-curfew-title-celebrations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/manuel-pellegrini-manchester-city-manager-data</link>
      <description>• Departing manager produces figures to show his success at City<br />• Pellegrini: ‘The only thing we couldn’t be best at was defence’<p>Manuel Pellegrini has prepared for his departure from Manchester City by making a strong defence of his record at the club and supplying what he considers hard evidence to support his claims that his three-year reign should not be regarded as disappointing.</p><p>Pellegrini will take charge of his final game, at Swansea City on Sunday, with the most expensively assembled team in the Premier League <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/11/pep-guardiola-manchester-city-europa-league-champions-league-football" title="">still not assured of being in the Champions League</a> when Pep Guardiola takes over in the summer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/manuel-pellegrini-manchester-city-manager-data">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>Kamara’s transfer comes days after penalty spat with Federico Higuain<br></li><li>Revs GM Michael Burns says: ‘Kei is a proven goalscorer in MLS’<br></li></ul><p>Less than a week after a very public spat with his team-mate over who should take a penalty kick, Columbus Crew have agreed to trade Kei Kamara, last season’s leading goalscorer, to New England Revolution for a record fee.       <title>The 100 best footballers in the world 2015 – interactive</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/ng-interactive/2015/dec/21/the-100-best-footballers-in-the-world-2015-interactive</link>
      <description><p>Welcome to the Guardian’s choice of the world’s top 100 footballers for 2015.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/play-off-goalfests-murali-magic-a-long-overdue-home-run-and-chalet-golf</link>
      <description><p>This week’s roundup also features ghost tackling, crowd surfing and Leeds United supporters finding new ways to amuse themselves</p><p>1) It’s play-offs time in the Football League which seems like a perfect excuse to cast our minds back to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5l_nrd5bBQw">Fabian de Freitas sweeping home</a>, a seven-goal thriller from 1993 <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X4K1530txPM">featuring Craig Maskell and the most satisfying in-off-the-post sound</a> ever heard at Wembley and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHFkFqVcFGo">Sunderland and Charlton going one better in a 4-4 draw in 1998</a> – poor old Michael Gray.</p><p>2) England begin their summer of cricket with the first Test against Sri Lanka at Headingley on Thursday, a full 10 years after Chamara Kapugedera ruined <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F-3SqsJvyGM">Murali’s fun at Trent Bridge</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/play-off-goalfests-murali-magic-a-long-overdue-home-run-and-chalet-golf">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Football teams relegated despite not being in the drop zone all season | The Knowledge</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/football-team-relegated-not-being-in-drop-zone-all-season-the-knowledge</link>
      <description><p>Plus: managers overseeing two relegations in one season, train stations v town size (2) and could Harry Kewell have played for England? Mail your questions to <a href="https://mail.google.com/mail/?view=cm&amp;fs=1&amp;tf=1&amp;to=knowledge@theguardian.com">knowledge@theguardian.com</a> or tweet <a href="https://twitter.com/theknowledge_gu">@TheKnowledge_GU</a></p><p><strong>“Just wanted to ask,”</strong> emails Aniket Joshi, <strong>“have there been any teams relegated on the final day of a league despite never having been in the relegation zone for the rest of the season?”</strong></p><p>The Premier League is often called the most competitive league in the world (of course, it isn’t even the most competitive league in the UK) but if you think this season in England’s top flight was one in which anybody could beat anybody, take a look at the 1908-09 First Division. A similar format – 20 teams, 38 matches for each team – yet the margins between the teams were tighter than a Floridian vote count. Well not quite, but they were close: by the end of the season, just four points separated Woolwich Arsenal in sixth and Manchester City in 19th. City had not been in the dreaded bottom two all season – in fact they had roared to the top of the league on the opening day owing to a 1-0 win against Sunderland (level points then decided by goal average – goals scored divided by goals conceded – thereby rewarding those who scored fewer goals) and had floated about in mid-table ever since, owing to their excellent home record (12 wins from 19, only The Wednesday, Sunderland and champions Newcastle had more) and dismal away record. The polar nature of the club was reflected on the terraces too, with attendances ranging from 40,000 to 3,000 throughout the campaign. Yet come the business end of the season, City were on the brink and lost their final match 1-0 away at Bristol City.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/football-team-relegated-not-being-in-drop-zone-all-season-the-knowledge">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Graeme Fowler and John Barclay books shed light on cricketers’ inner workings</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/graeme-fowler-john-barclay-the-spin</link>
      <description>Down-to-earth Lancastrian and Old Etonian former Sussex opener have each written about players’  lives in a way that takes us beyond first impressions<p>Most cricketers reveal a lot about themselves by the way they play. Watch Ian Botham or Ben Stokes bat and bowl and you surely get a fair reflection of their character. Deeds and demeanours on the field can be pretty reliable witnesses, though I always reckoned that Viv Richards was a notable exception. Has there ever been a more arrogant-looking entry to the arena than his as he ambled out to bat? He would wait until the stage was clear before stepping disdainfully onto grass privileged to feel the tread of his feet. Yet off the field Richards was one to shun the limelight; he was impeccably polite, self-effacing even, happier in the corner of the room.</p><p>So some cricketers can surprise us. They are not always quite what they seem. This thought occurred to me after two books had been squeezed through my letterbox recently. Both are the products of two peers of mine, who are capable of making us think again. The books are Absolutely Foxed by Graeme Fowler and Team Mates, a collection of essays compiled – or should I say cajoled into existence? – by John Barclay in order to raise funds for the Arundel Castle Cricket Foundation.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/10/graeme-fowler-john-barclay-the-spin">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Danny Willett’s first tournament since winning the Masters, Premier League relegation battle decided and the Women’s FA Cup final returns to Wembley<p>What do you do when you’ve stunned the world and won the Masters? Take a break and come back fresh for the <strong>Players&nbsp;Championship</strong>, the “fifth major”, at Sawgrass, of course. Danny Willett’s Augusta triumph – a 50-1 shot that came off before our perception of sporting odds was changed forever by Leicester City – was still stunning. He lines up alongside the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/11/danny-willett-masterrs-2016-jordan-spieth-lee-westood" title="">shellshocked man who put the Green Jacket on his back</a>, Jordan Spieth, and last year’s champion, Rickie Fowler, from Thursday before jetting across the Atlantic for the Irish Open and PGA Championship at Wentworth.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/07/the-agenda-danny-willett-premier-league-womens-fa-cup">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Joy of Six: football chants</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/06/the-joy-of-six-football-chants</link>
      <description><p>From Anfield’s unmistakable anthem to Barnsley’s glorious nihilism and existentialism among AFC Wimbledon fans – half a dozen of the best chants</p><p>When the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/apr/26/hillsborough-inquests-jury-says-96-victims-were-unlawfully-killed">jubilant, vindicated and visibly relieved families</a>, friends and supporters of the 96 Liverpool fans recently emerged from the inquest that confirmed what they’d all known for 27 years, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2016/apr/26/hillsborough-victims-families-sing-youll-never-walk-alone-after-verdict-video">there was only ever one song they were likely to sing</a>. There can scarcely have been a more sincere and heartfelt performance of a football chant that is always capable of prompting goosebumps regardless of one’s football allegiances.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/06/the-joy-of-six-football-chants">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>A secret Singaporean bank account is at the centre of allegations of institutionalised corruption at the IAAF. The account first came to prominence as the channel for the €300,000 refund paid to Russian marathon runner Liliya Shobukhova in March 2014.       <description><p>Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp says he has no timetable to make the club Premier League champions again.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2016/may/10/40-yard-goal-disallowed-goalcam-video</link>
      <description><p>During Saturday’s North West Counties League Premier Division match the Squires Gate player Joe Noblet was denied a goal after his 40-yard thunderbolt flew in off the post, but bounced back off the perimeter fence behind the goal so quickly the hapless officials did not realise what had happened and waved play on.
